metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: ECMAScript 2019
JavaScript Version Numbers
Old ECMAScript versions was named by numbers: ES5 and ES6.
content.html: Old ECMAScript versions was named by numbers: ES5 and ES6.

content.text: From 2016, versions are named by year: ES2016, 2018, 2020 ...
content.html: From 2016, versions are named by year: ES2016, 2018, 2020 ...

content.text: New Features in ES2019
JavaScript String trimStart()
ES2019 added the String method trimStart() to JavaScript.
content.html: ES2019 added the String method trimStart() to JavaScript.

content.text: The trimStart() method works like trim() , but removes whitespace only from the start of a string.
content.html: The trimStart() method works like trim(), but removes whitespace only from the start of a string.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let text1 = "     Hello World!     ";
let text2 = text1.trimStart();

content.code:
let text1 = "     Hello World!     ";
let text2 = text1.trimStart();

syntax_highlighting.text:
let text1 = "     Hello World!     ";
let text2 = text1.trimStart();

content.code_html:
let text1 = "     Hello World!     ";
let text2 = text1.trimStart();

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let text1 = "     Hello World!     ";
let text2 = text1.trimStart();

content.text: JavaScript String trimStart() is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:
content.html: JavaScript String trimStart() is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:

content.code_html:
Chrome 66 Edge 79 Firefox 61 Safari 12 Opera 50
Apr 2018 Jan 2020 Jun 2018 Sep 2018 May 2018

content.text: JavaScript String trimEnd()
ES2019 added the String method trimEnd() to JavaScript.
content.html: ES2019 added the String method trimEnd() to JavaScript.

content.text: The trimEnd() method works like trim() , but removes whitespace only from the end of a string.
content.html: The trimEnd() method works like trim(), but removes whitespace only from the end of a string.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let text1 = "     Hello World!     ";
let text2 = text1.trimEnd();

content.code:
let text1 = "     Hello World!     ";
let text2 = text1.trimEnd();

syntax_highlighting.text:
let text1 = "     Hello World!     ";
let text2 = text1.trimEnd();

content.code_html:
let text1 = "     Hello World!     ";
let text2 = text1.trimEnd();

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let text1 = "     Hello World!     ";
let text2 = text1.trimEnd();

content.text: JavaScript String trimEnd() is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:
content.html: JavaScript String trimEnd() is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:

content.code_html:
Chrome 66 Edge 79 Firefox 61 Safari 12 Opera 50
Apr 2018 Jan 2020 Jun 2018 Sep 2018 May 2018

content.text: JavaScript Object fromEntries()
ES2019 added the Object method fromEntries() to JavaScript.
content.html: ES2019 added the Object method fromEntries() to JavaScript.

content.text: The fromEntries() method creates an object from iterable key / value pairs.
content.html: The fromEntries() method creates an object from iterable key / value pairs.

content.code_html:
const fruits = [
["apples", 300],
["pears", 900],
["bananas", 500]
];

const myObj = Object.fromEntries(fruits);

content.text: JavaScript Object fromEntries() is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:
content.html: JavaScript Object fromEntries() is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:

content.code_html:
Chrome 73 Edge 79 Firefox 63 Safari 12.1 Opera 60
Mar 2019 Jan 2020 Oct 2018 Mar 2019 Apr 2019

content.text: Optional catch Binding
From ES2019 you can omit the catch parameter if you don't need it:.
content.html: From ES2019 you can omit the catch parameter if you don't need it:.

content.code_html:
try {
// code
 } catch (err) {
// code
 }

content.text: Optional catch binding is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:
content.html: Optional catch binding is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:

content.code_html:
Chrome 66 Edge 79 Firefox 58 Safari 11.1 Opera 53
Apr 2018 Jan 2020 Jan 2018 Mar 2018 May 2018

content.text: JavaScript Array flat()
ES2019 added the Array flat() method to JavaScript.
content.html: ES2019 added the Array flat() method to JavaScript.

content.text: The flat() method creates a new array by flattening a nested array.
content.html: The flat() method creates a new array by flattening a nested array.

content.code_html:
const myArr = [[1,2],[3,4],[5,6]];
const newArr = myArr.flat();

content.text: JavaScript Array flat() is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:
content.html: JavaScript Array flat() is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:

content.code_html:
Chrome 69 Edge 79 Firefox 62 Safari 12 Opera 56
Sep 2018 Jan 2020 Sep 2018 Sep 2018 Sep 2018

content.text: JavaScript Array flatMap()
ES2019 added the Array flatMap() method to JavaScript.
content.html: ES2019 added the Array flatMap() method to JavaScript.

content.text: The flatMap() method first maps all elements of an array and then creates a new array by flattening the array.
content.html: The flatMap() method first maps all elements of an array and then creates a new array by flattening the array.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const myArr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const newArr = myArr.flatMap(x => [x, x * 10]);

content.code:
const myArr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const newArr = myArr.flatMap(x => [x, x * 10]);

syntax_highlighting.text:
const myArr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const newArr = myArr.flatMap(x => [x, x * 10]);

content.code_html:
const myArr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const newArr = myArr.flatMap(x => [x, x * 10]);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const myArr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const newArr = myArr.flatMap(x => [x, x * 10]);

content.text: Stable Array sort()
ES2019 revised the Array sort() method.
content.html: ES2019 revised the Array sort() method.

content.text: Before 2019, the specification allowed unstable sorting algorithms such as QuickSort.
content.html: Before 2019, the specification allowed unstable sorting algorithms such as QuickSort.

content.text: After ES2019, browsers must use a stable sorting algorithm:
content.html: After ES2019, browsers must use a stable sorting algorithm:

content.text: When sorting elements on a value, the elements must keep their relative position to other elements with the same value.
content.html: When sorting elements on a value, the elements must keep their relative position to other elements with the same value.

content.code_html:
const myArr = [
  {name:"X00",price:100 },
  {name:"X01",price:100 },
  {name:"X02",price:100 },
  {name:"X03",price:100 },
  {name:"X04",price:110 },
  {name:"X05",price:110 },
  {name:"X06",price:110 },
  {name:"X07",price:110 }
];

content.text: In the example above, when sorting on price, the result should not have names in a different relative position, such as this:
content.html: In the example above, when sorting on price, the result should not have names in a different relative position, such as this:

content.code_html:
X01 100
X03 100
X00 100
X03 100
X05 110
X04 110
X06 110
X07 110

content.text: Revised JSON.stringify()
ES2019 revised the JSON stringify() method.
content.html: ES2019 revised the JSON stringify() method.

content.text: Before 2019, JSON could not stringify character encoded with \.
content.html: Before 2019, JSON could not stringify character encoded with \.

content.code_html: let text = JSON.stringify("\u26D4");

content.text: Before ES2019, using JSON.stringify() JSON on UTF-8 code points (U+D800 to U+DFFF) returned broken Unicode characters like ���.
content.html: Before ES2019, using JSON.stringify()JSON on UTF-8 code points (U+D800 to U+DFFF) returned broken Unicode characters like ���.

content.text: After this revision, strings with UTF-8 code points convert safely with JSON.stringify() , and back to the original using JSON.parse() .
content.html: After this revision, strings with UTF-8 code points convert safely with JSON.stringify(), and back to the original using JSON.parse().

content.text: Separator Symbols
Line separators and paragraph separator symbols (\u2028 and \u2029) are now allowed in string literals.
content.html: Line separators and paragraph separator symbols (\u2028 and \u2029) are now allowed in string literals.

content.text: Before 2019, these were treated as line terminators and resulted in error exceptions:
content.html: Before 2019, these were treated as line terminators and resulted in error exceptions:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// This is valid in ES2019:
let text = "\u2028";

content.code:
// This is valid in ES2019:
let text = "\u2028";

syntax_highlighting.text:
// This is valid in ES2019:
let text = "\u2028";

content.code_html:
// This is valid in ES2019:
 let text = "\u2028";

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// This is valid in ES2019:
let text = "\u2028";

content.text: Note
Now, JavaScript and JSON have equal rules.
content.html: Now, JavaScript and JSON have equal rules.

content.text: Before ES2019:
content.html: Before ES2019:

content.text: text = JSON.parse('"\u2028"') would parse to ''.
content.html: text = JSON.parse('"\u2028"') would parse to ''.

content.text: text = '"\u2028"' would give syntax error .
content.html: text = '"\u2028"' would give syntax error.

content.text: Revised Function toString()
ES2019 revised the Function toString() method.
content.html: ES2019 revised the Function toString() method.

content.text: The toString() method returns a string representing the source code of a function.
content.html: The toString() method returns a string representing the source code of a function.

content.text: From 2019, toString() must return the source code of the function including comments, spaces, and syntax details.
content.html: From 2019, toString() must return the source code of the function including comments, spaces, and syntax details.

content.text: Before 2019, different browsers returned different variants of the function (like without comments and spaces). From 2019 the function should be returned exactly as it is written.
content.html: Before 2019, different browsers returned different variants of the function (like without comments and spaces). From 2019 the function should be returned exactly as it is written.

content.code_html:
function myFunction(p1, p2) {
  return p1 * p2;
}
